questions.question:
Question 1: A patient is asked to do incentive spirometry after his surgery. Which of the following 
muscles would he use while expiring into the device shown?
questions.explanation:
The internal intercostal muscles are the muscles of expiration. The device shown in the image is an incentive spirometer. It is a device used to help your lungs 
recover after surgery or a lung illness. 852 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not an accessory muscle of inspiration?
questions.explanation:
Latissimus dorsi is not an accessory muscle of inspiration. It is an accessory muscle of expiration. Accessory muscles of inspiration: • Sternocleidomastoid • Scalene muscles • Serratus posterior and anterior • Errector spinae • Pectoralis major and minor Breathing involves changing the thoracic volume by altering the vertical, transverse, and 
anteroposterior dimensions of the thorax. The diaphragm is the key muscle in respiration. Serratus posterior superior elevates the ribs, hence aiding in inspiration. Serratus posterior 
inferior depresses the ribs. It is a muscle aiding in expiration.

questions.question:
Question 3: 845 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following do not elevate the ribs?
questions.explanation:
Serratus posterior inferior does not elevate the ribs. The muscles of inspiration help increase the diameters of the thoracic cavity by elevating the ribs. 
Serratus posterior inferior is an accessory muscle of expiration. The muscles of expiration help in 
the depression of the ribs. Mnemonic: SIT-Q depressors that work along with anterior abdominals for expiration: • Serratus posterior inferior • Internal intercostals 853 
Sold by @itachibot • Transversus thoracis • Quadratus lumborum

questions.question:
Question 4: You are interpreting the lateral neck Å-ray of a patient who has multiple bruises on his face 
and neck. To look for tracheal injuries, you will start looking from which level?
questions.explanation:
The trachea starts at the level of the inferior border of the cricoid cartilage at the level of the C6 
vertebra.

questions.question: Question 5: At which vertebral level does the trachea bifurcate?
questions.explanation:
The trachea bifurcates at the lower border of T4 vertebra. The trachea is 10 - 12 cm long and has 2 parts: • Upper cervical • Thoracic(in superior mediastinum) Note: Although Gray's Anatomy 41st Ed states that the tracheal bifurcation is at T6, we choose to 
stick with T4 as multiple other textbooks give the answer as T4.

questions.question: Question 6: Left bronchus crosses esophagus at
questions.explanation: The left bronchus crosses the esophagus at 28 cm from the upper incisor teeth. Normally esophagus shows 4 constrictions at the following levels measured from upper incisors: • Junction of the esophagus with cricopharynx (15 cm from the incisor teeth) • Crossed by arch of aorta (23 cm from the incisor teeth) • Crossed by left bronchus (28 cm from the incisor teeth) • It pierces the diaphragm (40 cm from the incisor teeth)

questions.question:
Question 7: You are asked to do thoracentesis for a patient with mild pleural effusion on the left side. You 
are being cautious while inserting a needle in the left midaxillary line of the patient. You 
would not insert the needle below which level so as not to damage the surrounding 
structures?
questions.explanation:
The inferior margin of the pleura in the midaxillary line is at the level of the 10th rib. So, while 
doing thoracentesis you would not go below this level. It is done in the 8th or 9th intercostal space 
so as not to damage the surrounding structures.

questions.question:
Question 8: You are asked to mark the oblique fissure of the lung on a cadaver. Which of the following 
landmarks will not touch the line while drawing surface markings for this fissure?
questions.explanation:
The surface marking of the oblique fissure of the lung will not touch 4th costal cartilage. 854 
Sold by @itachibot On either side, the upper and lower lobes of the lung are separated by the oblique fissure. This can be marked by a line that runs anteroinferiorly from the posterior end of the 4th rib (the 
spinous process of the T3 vertebra), crosses the 5th rib in the midaxillary line, continues 
inferiorly, crossing either the 6th intercostal space/ 7th rib on the right or the 5th rib/ 5th 
intercostal space on the left, on both sides at the midclavicular line. The left oblique fissure is located at a higher level and courses more vertically than the right 
oblique fissure.

questions.question:
Question 9: A young man is rushed to the emergency department after suffering a stab wound over the 
chest wall. The entry wound is present on the left side in the mid-clavicular line. The lung is 
likely to not be injured if the entry wound is below which level? 847 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The lower border of the lung in the midclavicular line is at the level of the 6th rib. Hence, if the 
entry wound is below this level, the lung is probably not injured. 855 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: What does the pleural cupola refer to?
questions.explanation:
The dome-shaped layer of parietal pleura lining the cervical extension of the pleural cavity is 
called cervical pleura/pleural cupola/dome of pleura.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presented with cough, haemoptysis, and unexplained weight 
loss. CT-scan revealed a ■tumor in the right lung invading the mediastinal pleura. The 
patient is likely to experience referred pain in which of the following regions?
questions.explanation:
The pain from mediastinal pleura is referred to the side of the neck. Pleura 
Innervation 
Pain referred to Costaland peripheral diaphra 
gmatic pleura Intercostal nerves 
Thoracic or abdominal wall Lateral neck and supraclavic 
ular region Mediastinaland Central diap 
hragmatic pleura Phrenic nerve (C3, C4, and C 
5)

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following structures is related to the mediastinal part of the right lung?
questions.explanation: Superior vena cava is related to the mediastinal part of the right lung.

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following is a posterior relation to the root of the right lung? 848 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The vagus nerve is posterior to the root of the lung. The roots of the lung are at the level of T5-T7 vertebral bodies. The phrenic nerve is anterior to the 
root of the lung.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following structures is related to the area marked 'A' in the diagram below?
questions.explanation:
The area marked 'A' is where the azygos vein arches over the hilum of the right lung. The diagram shown is of the right lung, identified by the presence of hyparterial and eparterial 
bronchus at the hilum.

questions.question: Question 15: Which is the most superior structure at the hilum of the left lung?
questions.explanation:
The sequence of structures at the left hilum superior to inferior is: (Mnemonic: 'ABV') 856 
Sold by @itachibot • Pulmonary artery, • Principal (hyparterial) bronchus • Inferior pulmonary vein The sequence of structures at the right hilum superior to inferior is: (Mnemonic: 'BABV') • Superior lobar (eparterial) bronchus • Pulmonary artery • Principal bronchus • Inferior pulmonary vein

questions.question: Question 16: What is the inferior most structure of the right hilum?
questions.explanation: The inferior most structure of the right hilum is the inferior pulmonary vein. The sequence of structures at the right hilum superior to inferior is: (Mnemonic - 'BABV') • Superior lobar (eparterial) bronchus • Pulmonary artery • Principal bronchus • Inferior pulmonary vein

questions.question: Question 17: Which is not a lobe of lungs?
questions.explanation:
Lingula is not a lobe. It is a small process that is usually present at the lower end of the cardiac 
notch of the left lung. The right lung has 3 lobes: • Superior • Middle • Inferior The left lung has 2 lobes: • Superior • Inferior 857 
Sold by @itachibot Note: The azygos vein may sometimes course in a more lateral position, within a four-layered 
pleural septum within the superior lobe, creating an ‘azygos lobe’. This is not a true lobe, but a 
separated portion of the superior lobe that lacks its own bronchi, arteries, or veins.

questions.question: Question 18: How many bronchopulmonary segments are there in the right and left lungs, respectively?
questions.explanation:
Both the lungs have 10 bronchopulmonary segments each. The functionally independent unit of lung tissue is called a bronchopulmonary segment. Each 
segment is a separate respiratory unit.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 40-year-old male smoker was diagnosed to have carcinoma of the right lung. Bronchogram 
showed the presence of a tumor, causing partial occlusion of the eparterial bronchus. Which 
of the following bronchopulmonary segments are likely to receive decreased airflow■?
questions.explanation:
The eparterial bronchus supplies the right upper lobe, which includes the segments: apical, 
posterior, and anterior. Hence, these segments will have decreased airflow.

questions.question: Question 20: Bronchopulmonary segments are aerated by which of the following bronchi?
questions.explanation:
The bronchopulmonary segments are aerated by tertiary bronchi (3°). Principal bronchi (1°) ---> lobar bronchi (2° - right into 3, left into 2) ---> segmental bronchi 
(3°) 858 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following statements is false regarding the bronchopulmonary segment?

options.b: It is named according to the segmental bronchus supplying it
options.c: It is drained by independent intrasegmental branch of pulmonary vein
options.d: It is the largest subdivision of a lobe

questions.explanation:
The bronchopulmonary segments are not drained by an independent branch of the pulmonary 
vein. The tributaries of the pulmonary vein tend to pass intersegmentally between and around the 
margins of segments. A bronchopulmonary segment is the area of lung supplied by a segmental bronchus and its 
accompanying pulmonary artery branch and can be resected surgically. It is the largest division of 
a lobe. 859 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 22: A 2-year-old child is brought to the ED due to choking. Examination showed decreased breath 
sounds on the right side. An inhaled foreign body lodged in the right bronchus is suspected. 
Which of the following is not an explanation for this presentation?

options.a: Right lung is shorter and wider than the left
options.b: Right principal bronchus is more vertical than the left bronchus
options.c: Tracheal bifurcation directs the foreign body to the right lung
options.d: Right inferior lobar bronchus is in continuation with the principal bronchus

questions.explanation:
The right principal bronchus (not the right lung) is wider, shorter (2.5 cm), and more vertical than 
the left. The right inferior lobar bronchus is the continuation of the bronchus intermedius which 
is in the continuation of the right principal bronchus. These differences explain why inhaled 
foreign bodies enter the right principal bronchus more often than the left. The left principal bronchus is narrower, longer (5 cm) and less vertical than the right principal 
bronchus.

questions.question: Question 23: Up to which level does the bronchial artery supplies blood to the lungs?
questions.explanation:
The bronchial artery supplies the lungs up to the respiratory bronchiole. Bronchial arteries are derived from the descending thoracic aorta either directly or indirectly. 
They travel and branch with the bronchi, and terminate around the level of the respiratory 
bronchioles. Pulmonary arteries alone perfuse the further distal pathways including the alveolar ducts and the 
alveoli. 860 
Sold by @itachibot Anterior Abdominal Wall
